fields.description: In Bamboo 5.7.2 the signup feature is broken due to a bug with how the CAPTCHA is parsed.
fields.summary: Signup broken due to CAPTCHA bug

fields.description:
Bamboo claims it will look up the service record for instant messaging if you leave the port blank: 

"If no port is specified, Bamboo will first perform a DNS SRV lookup or use the default port."

However, if you specify "Requires an TLS/SSL connection" then it will not look up the service record and will use port 5222/5223 and the specified host name instead.

This seems to be a very longstanding bug.

Workarounds (not good workarounds):
* Don't specify requiring a secure connection (a secure connection should still be used if available)
* Don't use DNS SRV lookup and instead specify the direct host and portname.
fields.summary: Requiring TLS/SSL breaks DNS SRV lookup
Run Summary does not report Tests Accurately

fields.description:
The option to 'Enable Repository Caching on Remote Agents' is present for Bitbucket repo type despite [BAM-15147|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15147]

However, if you attempt to check the setting checkbox and save the repository settings the config isn't actually saved. Please see the attached video.
fields.summary: "Enable Repository Caching on Remote Agents" option exists for Bitbucket repos but does not work.

fields.description:
h6. Steps to reproduce
# create application link between Bamboo v5.7.2 and Stash v3.6.0
# create a repository in Stash
# commit something to the repository
# create a Project / Plan in Bamboo
# set up Stash repository in "{{Plan configuration >> Repositories}}" tab
# under "{{Plan configuration >> Triggers}}" tab, select "{{Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed}}" as "{{Trigger type}}"
# under "{{Plan configuration >> Branches}}" tab, enable "{{Create plan branches for branches detected in the repository}}"
# run your build
# disable your build Plan
# create a new Branch
{code}
git checkout -b newbranch
{code}
# commit something to the "{{newbranch}}"

You will notice a new branch will be displayed under the Plan in Bamboo and the same will trigger a build.
fields.summary: Branches are created/triggered even with Plan disabled

# Run deployment
# Delete the release. This will delete the release but retains the deployment history
# Now try to delete the deployment logs

fields.description:
When using Crowd for SSO, we identify in the config file that:

"...Enable it after configuring your Crowd properties through user management and restart Bamboo. It does not support Crowd property changes at runtime..."

However, we still allow for the modification of the parameters inside the Bamboo UI  and this can cause Bamboo to hang, as a restart is required to correctly implement the change.

Correct this by addition of suitable warning that a reboot would be required, or, disable the ability to make the change when SSO is enabled.
fields.summary: Warn users that config change will require a restart

fields.description:
I have deployment plan, which does the following:
# Clean working directory
# Download artifacts, includes:
#- Artifact A
#- Artifact B
#- Artifact C
# Upload artifact A to server 1
# Upload artifact B to server 2
# Upload artifact C to server 3

However, instead of uploading each of the three artifacts to their appropriate servers, Bamboo uploads all three artifacts to all three servers (so artifact A, B and C all end up on servers 1,2 and 3). Since artifact C is a collection of quite a few files, my deployment plan is now taking a lot longer than is needed, besides that, I am uploading useless files to all my servers.
fields.summary: Bamboo uploads all artifacts, while it should upload only one.

fields.description: There is a typo in the Deleting Deployment Details UI where we suggest that that a customer will "loose", rather than "lose", informaiton.
fields.summary: Deleting deployment details spelling error

fields.description:
I use the git-flow model and one thing that would be really nice is to be able to pick any arbitrary build on my 'develop' or 'release' branch and merge it to 'master'. This represents a production release.

The interface for this would work like deployments. Each build page would have a button called "Merge", which would be enabled if the "Manual Merge" automatic merge type is selected. This would work like Gatekeeper except that it won't be doing the merge for each successful build, but instead only the successful build that I choose.

Right now to release to production I have to do this through Git, but having an interface through Bamboo to do this merge would enable teams like QA to control advancing phases of deployment.
fields.summary: Add new "Manual Merge" type to automatic merging

fields.description:
If the plan name has a hyphen surrounded by spaces: {{ - }} and that plan is branched the rest of the string behind the words preceding the hyphen is truncated.

Plan name:
!plan_config.png|thumbnail!



It shows correctly on the branch summary page:
!branch_summary.png|thumbnail!



But truncates on the build activity page:
!build_activity.png|thumbnail!



You can see where the trunk/master plan displays properly but the branch truncates everything starting before the hyphen.
fields.summary: Hyphen in plan name of branch plan causes incorrectly displayed plan name in build activity screen

fields.description:
Though there aren't many use cases where a user will just manually create branches instead of having Bamboo manage it automatically they should still be able to utilize the automatic cleanup function.

Workarounds:
* Upgrade to 5.9 where it is fixed 
* If upgrading to 5.9 is not possible, enable branch creation and set a regex that will not match any branches. E.g. dummyRegexToMatchNothing
fields.summary: When automatic branch detection is disabled the automatic branch cleanup job doesn't run

fields.summary: Invalid checkoutBranch key in the xml_definition_data of the build_definition table

fields.description:
Moving plans may potentially cause inconsistencies in the build table where incorrect branch keys are inserted into the build table.

If you moved plans and restarted Bamboo, that could cause the same issue. Meaning, contrary to the first impression you might have after reading the logs, this won't happen necessarily during an upgrade task. The following can be seen in the logs:
{noformat:title=atlassian-bamboo.log}
2015-06-04 10:05:23,636 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AbstractUpgradeManager] Completed task 4410 with errors.
2015-06-04 10:05:23,636 FATAL [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBootstrapManager] Pre-bootstrap validation tests failed: [Task for build 4410 failed:, com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey: There 
are invalid branch keys in the BUILD table: [BIS-SNATRUNK3]]
{noformat}
*Workaround:*
If you're hitting this and your instance is down, the following procedure should be applied so you can get your instance up and running:

1. Stop your Bamboo instance.

2. With Bamboo stopped navigate to
{code:java}
<Bamboo Install Directory>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes
{code}
and open the {{upgrades.xml}} file.

3. Find the following line:
{code:xml}
<upgrade build="4410" build-min="4410" build-max="9999"             class="com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey"/>
{code}
and update it by commenting out the entry to:
{code:xml}
<!-- <upgrade build="4410" build-min="4410" build-max="9999" class="com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey"/> -->
{code}
4. Save the file Restart Bamboo.

5. Get an export of your instance.

6. Raise an issue with [https://support.atlassian.com|https://support.atlassian.com/] and attach your [export|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Exporting+data+for+backup] so we can double check the database consistency.

7. Once that's done, you should set your {{upgrades.xml}} back to uncomment the tag you commented out on the step #4 of this procedure.
fields.summary: Invalid branch keys in the build table

fields.description:
Dear Atlassian,

How do I configure this scenario:
 1. New branch created with first commit on Stash
 2. First build by automatic branch detection
 3. Second commit pushed to Stash
 4. Second build by Stash trigger

So far I have 1-2-3 working using the branch detection as documented. But in 4. the Stash trigger seems to be ignored by Bamboo. 

It only works when I *manually* tick the box "Change Trigger" in the plan branch. But I already have the Stash trigger configured in the parent plan, and I want to avoid this manual step!

What's going on?
fields.summary: I want Stash triggered auto-builds on auto-created plan branches.

fields.description:
Right now, the first build for a plan is a magical unicorn, that only appears once it already has an agent allocated and it's running on it. This makes the Build Activity view a lie, because when branch builds are enabled, there is almost always a significant backlog of jobs that are going to run, but are not listed on any of the queues. No amount of rejigging jobs in that queue can move them ahead of the first build for a plan.

Bamboo should create a queue entry for the first build of a plan, so it can be managed along with all the other jobs.
fields.summary: Show the first build of a plan in the build queue

fields.description:
Looking at one of our build servers today, the build activity shows that there are 3,902 errors logged in the past days. But when trying to view them through the admin ui, the page times out after a minute or so (and I just get a nice electric charlie).

I suggest to limit the number of errors returned by the initial page load of {{/admin/systemErrors.action}} to a limit of 500 and offer e.g. a pagination or lazy loading to fetch the remainin errors as I need them.

Bonus points for allowing me to group / filter errors with the same problem (e.g. exclude all _Unable to detect changes_ errors).

*Impact*
I'm currently unable to view the system error page due to the high number of errors. I don't know how to reduce the number of errors, AFAIK the _Clear all error logs_ button is only on the page itself.
fields.summary: Results returned on the system error page should be limited to the most 500 errors

fields.description:
I got 2 build plans (BP1 & BP2) with each having a branch plan called feature/x. BP2 is dependent on BP1's shared artifact but when I execute BP2 using feature/x branch it keeps downloading BP1's develop branch artifact although BP1's feature/x branch artifact is available.

I've managed to solve this issue by making sure the display name of branch feature/x for both build plans are the same but it would be nice if the artifact sharing is dependent on the source repository branch instead.
fields.summary: Artifact download should be dependent on branch name not display name.

fields.description:
When migrating Bamboo from Windows onto Linux or vice-versa, you could have the following error:
{noformat}
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: File '/bamboo/bamboo-home\xml-data\configuration/administration.xml' does not exist
{noformat}

The reason for that is Windows uses backslahes to navigate into directories while Linux uses forward slashes.

On *Windows*, under "{{<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}}" you will have:
{noformat}
...
    <property name="bamboo.artifacts.directory">${bambooHome}\artifacts</property>
    <property name="bamboo.config.directory">${bambooHome}\xml-data\configuration</property>
...
    <property name="bamboo.project.directory">${bambooHome}\xml-data\builds</property>
    <property name="buildWorkingDir">${bambooHome}\xml-data\build-dir</property>
    <property name="daily.backup.dir">${bambooHome}\backups</property>
...
    <property name="lucene.index.dir">${bambooHome}\index</property>
    <property name="webwork.multipart.saveDir">${bambooHome}\temp</property>
{noformat}

While on *Linux*, you should find the following:
{noformat}
...
    <property name="bamboo.artifacts.directory">${bambooHome}/artifacts</property>
    <property name="bamboo.config.directory">${bambooHome}/xml-data/configuration</property>
...
    <property name="bamboo.project.directory">${bambooHome}/xml-data/builds</property>
    <property name="buildWorkingDir">${bambooHome}/xml-data/build-dir</property>
    <property name="daily.backup.dir">${bambooHome}/backups</property>
...
    <property name="lucene.index.dir">${bambooHome}/index</property>
    <property name="webwork.multipart.saveDir">${bambooHome}/temp</property>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Update Bamboo's migration documentation

fields.description: When I first ran across the ability to Link a JIRA Issue to a Bamboo Test Case that was generated by JUnit.  I thought that was a cool idea.  So I went ahead created a bugfix issue and resolved the problem.  Now however the same Test Case has broken for a different reason and I need to link a different JIRA Issue to the same test case.  But I cannot because Bamboo Test Cases only support one JIRA Issue per Test Case.  I believe an Improvement would be to make it so multiple JIRA Issues can be linked to a Bamboo Test Case.
fields.summary: Bamboo Cannot Link Multiple JIRA Issues to a single test case

fields.description:
When bamboo stops working it leaves behind lock files. With these lock files in place bamboo won't start. Please simplify the process of deleting these lock files.

Example of how to break bamboo: start the bamboo service, start it again (don't use restart).
fields.summary: Simplify resolving server issues - lock file cleanup

fields.description: At present build logs are full of a log of information about the bamboo environment which can make it hard to find meaningful information such as what scripts were executed and with what options. Add an option to configure what goes into build logs.
fields.summary: Log verbosity setting

fields.description:
AWS has released new C4 instances; it should be possible for Bamboo users to use them for elastic agents too.

Details on the new instance type: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/now-available-new-c4-instances/
fields.summary: Add support for elastic agents in C4 Amazon instances

fields.description:
h3. ***Summary***
Due to the infrastructure problem on Amazon (connectivity issue between EC2 and S3), the agents keeps timing out.

h3. ***Feature Improvement Request***
I would be beneficial if there was a better status message to reflect this.
fields.summary: Status Message for Agent

fields.description: A plan with 18,000 unit tests is taking 1.7GB to process.
fields.summary: Bamboo OOMes when dealing with large numbers of unit tests

fields.description:
Granting permissions to create a plan will also grant the ability to a user to modify the definition of a linked repository. 

Some customers would find it beneficial to have this permission separated to ensure that an previously defined repository can not be accidentally or maliciously redefined.

Separating out an additional permission to "Edit Linked Repository" would assist in this. (Moving this to an admin level would not be desirable as this is still a level that non-admins would need.)
fields.summary: Separate Plan Creation permission and ability to edit linked repositories

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently Bamboo does not have a way to succinctly show permissions for users / groups across a large number of plans for audit purpose.

h3. Suggested Solution

Report that summarizes effective permissions for users and groups granted across multiple (or all) plans. Global permissions should also be considered.
 
h3. Workaround 
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/how-to-retrieve-user-and-group-access-mappings-permissions-from-the-bamboo-database-859516551.html
fields.summary: Bamboo Permissions Audit Report

fields.description:
Create a deployment whose deploy script randomly either finishes in five seconds or hangs for an hour. Schedule a trigger to kick off the deploys every five minutes.

Actual: When the first hanging deploy (call it "deploy-1") is running, deploy-2, deploy-3, deploy-4, etc. will stack up. When deploy-1 is finally finished, deploy-12 will kick off and run to completion. At that point, even though there are no currently running deploys, the stacked up deployments (deploy-2, deploy-3 ... deploy-11) will all still say that they're "Waiting" but their moment will never come.

Expected: Don't trigger a deployment while a deployment is currently running. The only deployment after deploy-1 should be deploy-2, even if deploy-1 takes an hour.

Apropos https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/10/BSP-16092
fields.summary: Junk deploy builds stack up if the current deploy gets stuck

fields.description:
I have the latest version of the Branchinator plugin installed (v1.22). 

When I view branches which have a special character in the name, e.g. feature/ASC-2346-mantle-nuget-deps, the URL encodes the / with %252F, e.g. http://bamboo/branchinator/17661966/ascendon-core/feature%252FASC-2346-mantle-nuget-deps. I am able to initially view the page but when I refresh the page, or click on Build -> Branch View (which immediately redirects to the last branch viewed), a 404 error is returned. 

After manually modifying the URL to change %252F to a -, the page loads correctly.
fields.summary: Branchinator returns 404 for branches with special characters

fields.description:
*Overall Behavior:*
* Occasionally, Hipchat notifications for both builds and deploys are not received.
* Trying the exact same deploy or build multiple times in quick succession results in only about 4 out of 5 of those builds or deploys sending notifications.
* This kind of behavior has been observed on our installation of Bamboo for more than a year now
* This same kind of inconsistent notifications behavior was also observed with IM notifications, which was what was used before we migrated to Hipchat
* Types of notifications used:
** Build: Failed Builds And First Successful
** Deploy: Deployment Started and Finished
fields.summary: Inconsistent Receiving of Hipchat Notifications
Build is successful when Maven fails and tests are quarantined

Unable to retrieve GitHub repository URL using Bamboo variables

# Create build plan

(i) URL not returned
fields.summary: need repositoryURL build variable for GitHub

fields.description:
Our configuration has 14 deployment projects and 117 deployment environments. The deployment page is quite slow and shows a lot of information - not all of which is relevant to the task at hand.

Currently, the top menu contains Deploy > All Deployment Projects - and that is all. There doesn't appear to be any way to add additional menu items beneath the Deploy menu (I did search for this feature - perhaps I am missing something. It would seem that this was the original intent, otherwise why would there be a drop down menu?)

It would be nice if a deployment project could be marked as a 'Favourite', or flagged in a similar way, and if the Deploy menu listed all of these flagged deployment projects beneath the menu. This would then allow the user to easily navigate directly to the dashboard for that deployment project (with a restricted view) instead of going through the 'All Deployment Projects' dashboard. This should be pretty straightforward, as the deployment project summary view is already available.

This may go some way towards helping us work around the very poor performance of the full deployment dashboard when there are many deployment projects and environments (see BAM-13643)
fields.summary: Provide the ability to add deployment projects to the Deploy drop down menu

fields.description:
Our continuous deployment workflow uses release flags (approved, broken) to determine if a release should be promoted to next deployment phase.
For example if a release is flagged as approved by QA leader then this will trigger a deployment to staging deployment environment.

Currently we can only trigger deployments based on schedule and successful builds. See https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Triggers+for+deployment+environments

We would like to be able to trigger deployments to specific environment based on release approval flag.
fields.summary: trigger deployments based on release flagged approved

The script works if I run it from the command prompt or from windows (Windows Server 2008 R2 Standard with SP1, 64-bit ).
fields.summary: Cannot run Matlab or any program in the batch script

fields.description:
Currently a build can have multiple parent plans and be set to check that the parent plan is concluding successfully before building. However, if just a single one of those parent plans is successful, the child build will be triggered regardless of the status of the other 'parents'.

It would be great if Bamboo had the ability to check multiple 'parent' builds for success before launching the child plan. This feature would be similar to the 'trigger conditions' for standard Bamboo build triggers.
fields.summary: Allow dependent plans to check multiple parent plans before building

fields.description:
In [this page on our website|https://www.atlassian.com/licensing/purchase-licensing#licensing-8] we say that the Developer license is based on the Commercial / Academic license, so it has the same expiry date.

However, it does not say anything regarding the number of remote agents allowed by the Bamboo Developer license. I do realize that page talks about Developer licenses in general and it applies to other products as well, not only to Bamboo.

So maybe this can be made more clear here instead: 
https://www.atlassian.com/licensing/bamboo
fields.summary: Clarify how many remote agents are allowed by Developer licenses

fields.description:
As it stands now, under "{{Plan configuration >> Dependencies}}" tab there is a "{{Child plans}}" dropdown menu that:
* uses a special character to separate Project and Plans (i.e.: MyProject › MyPlan)
{noformat}
›
›
›)
{noformat}
* only list 10 results

This also occurs on *Create deployment project* (newDeploymentProjectDetails) and *Update deployment project* (configureDeploymentProjectDetails).

Instead, it would be easier to search if:
* no special characters were used
* dropdown list was scrollable

h5. Workaround
Right-click on the dropdown menu and open "Inspect Element" in Chrome, for example. This action will provide you with the following:
!bamboo.chrome.inspectElement.png|thumbnail!
_you will be able to copy the information you are looking for (in green, Project › To Production A)_
fields.summary: Difficult to search for build plan for Dependencies and Deployments
Actually it is impossible to evaluate the last exit code in a final task

fields.description:
As described in Answers here ...
    https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/53869/is-there-any-way-to-manually-clear-a-workspace-in-bamboo

    ... there is a desire to sometimes run a clean build. I need that today, but it's a rare occurence. The suggestion is either:
    1) Change the Checkout Source task to "Force Clean Build" ... but then I have to go into the same configuration later and uncheck it. I'm trying to do this just once.
    2) Create a plan variable for cleaning the source tree. The suggestion works pretty good, but requires both:

        the user to be using git (as opposed to SubVersion)
        the user to do all that work in Ant or in a script to look for the variable and run that conditionally.

    The "Run custom..." already asks the user a question about the checkout. It asks for a revision number (see attachment). To me, doing a clean build is a Custom Build thing to do, and it's something related to the checkout, right next to the existing question. This customizable build option should come out-of-the-box as a feature with Bamboo.

    This way, I can reset my build to take into account dependency-changes that aren't fully declared, forcing everything to be remade. This will allow  my developers' builds to go green faster, without any custom work – no build-engineer or admin involved.
fields.summary: Custom build: force clean build

fields.description:
Hi,

We use Bamboo 5.6 and connect to Stash for our Repositories.
The plan is set to cleanup branches after 3 days and branches are set to be automatically detected, which is how they are created.

However we notice that the old branches are never removed, just left in a disabled state.
In Stash, branches are just merged back into Develop, sometimes deleted on marge and occassionally manually deleted.

We don't explicity set the option to "do not clean up plan branch auto".

Can you please investigate why these branches aren't being deleted.
fields.summary: Build Plan Branches don't automatically clean up.

fields.description:
h4. Issue
Deployment trigger changes are not saved properly if modified from _After Successful Build Plan_ to _Scheduled_

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create a deployment trigger of type _After Successful Build Plan_ and Save
# Change the type to  _Scheduled_ and save
# Run the build plan

h4. Expected results
The deployment will NOT trigger after the build plan

h4. Actual results
The deployment triggers regardless of the trigger settings

h4. Notes
The bug can only be reproduce if the trigger is *modified* to _Scheduled_. After modifying it, the deployment will trigger even if the trigger is removed.

h4. Workaround
* Remove the trigger, clone the environment and delete the original environment
* Avoid modifying the trigger. Delete and recreate instead
fields.summary: Deployment trigger changes are not saved properly

fields.description: Could you please add "{{<bamboo-install>/conf/server.xml}}" to be included in the Bamboo Support Zip "{{Bamboo Administration >> System >> Atlassian Support Tools >> Support Zip >> Create}}", in the same way as Stash, Confluence and JIRA does, please?
fields.summary: Add Bamboo's server.xml to the Support Zip

fields.description:
Consider Plan A and B that are in charge of building two components. Plan C takes shared artifacts from A and B and creates an installer. A deployment project is setup, linked to Plan C, which deploys that installer. When creating a release on that deployment project, only commits to Plan C are checked for JIRA issue tags. Any commits to Plan A or Plan B that had JIRA issues do not show up as a "issue" for this release. 

It seems that deployment projects will only work for very simple developments that can fit inside one Plan.

Please add the ability (or the option to enable the ability) to traverse the dependency tree to find all issues between releases.
fields.summary: Issue detected on Deployment Project don't traverse dependency tree to find parent plans

fields.description: It would be nice to have an additional trigger type for deployments: 'After successful deployment' which would allow to start a deployment depending of the result of another deployment. Use case: Separate plans to deploy config files and tomcat archives.
fields.summary: Trigger deployment after successful deployment

After start deploy on our production, we see most all the time "No logs found." But some times some part of logs (several lines) appears on couple of seconds, and dissapear again.

After deployment finished, log file has only one line, and couple of minutes later it appears full but mixed in time.


We have our production server (and deployment bamboo agent) in US and our bamboo server in Europe, the internet connection is slow and high latency

Bamboo version 5.7.0 build 5714 - 06 Nov 14
fields.summary: Deployment log displayed incorrectly during deployment proccess, and the final log is mixed in time

h3. Steps to reproduce
1. Create parent plan
2. Create child plan with one manual stage
3. In parent plan depedencies set child plan to be triggered on succesful build of parent plan
4. Trigger parent plan with a commit
5. Parent plan is build succesfully
6. Child plan is triggered
7. Run manual stage in child plan build

h3. Expected behavior
- in child plan I can see revision number that triggered parent plan
- in child plan I can see list of commits that triggered child plan

h3. Actual behavior
- I don't see revision number in child plan
- I don't see list of commits that triggered child plan

fields.description:
Hi,

I have an instance of Bamboo (version 5.5.1 currently) on which I have multiple plans running Fitnesse tests.
I am able to parse Fitnesse results into JUnit format in order to make them readable by Bamboo JUnit Parser.

My need is to be able to display HTML when tests are failing or in error, but it seems that this is not possible right now. I tried with pure HTML directly in the <failure> or <error> tags, but log says that JUnit Parser could not read the file; secondly with encoded HTML but then it is only displayed as simple text (see screenshot).

Can anyone tell me if there is a solution to display HTML in the build results ? I had a look at the market place but found no add-ons for that.

Thanks.

fields.description:
When requiring client SSL certificates on bamboo, the bamboo agents do not set the correct SSL context and are unable to find the required client certificate.  Variables are set in the wrapper.conf.  These work for the when activemq authenticates with client certificate, but not for the initial https:-connection of the agent.

This issue is a major blocker for securely authenticating build agents.

The wrapper.conf parameters are set like this:
wrapper.java.additional.2=-
Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore="C:\Users\oberg\client.ks"
wrapper.java.additional.3=-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=secret
wrapper.java.additional.4=-Djavax.net.debug=ssl
wrapper.java.additional.5=-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore="C:\Users\oberg\trust.ks"
wrapper.java.additional.6=-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=secret

This works fine for the truststore:
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2015/01/15 23:19:35 | trustStore is: C:\Users\oberg\trust.ks
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2015/01/15 23:19:35 | trustStore type is : jks

But it fails to read/use the proper client certificates from the keystore, ending in a empty client certificate chain, and thus SSL connection failure:

INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | *** CertificateRequest
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | Cert Types: RSA, DSS, ECDSA
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | Cert Authorities:
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | <EMAILADDRESS=olaf.trygve.berglihn@sintef.no, CN=code.sintef.no CA, O=SINTEF>
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | <CN=Sintef Group PKI, DC=sintef, DC=no>
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | <EMAILADDRESS=olaf.trygve.berglihn@sintef.no, CN=Olaf Trygve Berglihn, O=SINTEF, C=no>
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | *** ServerHelloDone
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | *** Certificate chain
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | ***
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | *** ECDHClientKeyExchange

...

INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | verify_data:  { 181, 187, 117, 80, 242, 91, 237, 83, 223, 19, 148, 95 }
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | ***
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | WrapperSimpleAppMain, WRITE: TLSv1 Handshake, length = 48
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | WrapperSimpleAppMain, waiting for close_notify or alert: state 1
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | WrapperSimpleAppMain, Exception while waiting for close java.net.SocketException: Software caused connection abort: recv failed
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | WrapperSimpleAppMain, handling exception: java.net.SocketException: Software caused connection abort: recv failed
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | %% Invalidated:  [Session-1, TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA]
INFO   | jvm 2    | 2015/01/15 23:19:40 | WrapperSimpleAppMain, IOException in getSession():  java.net.SocketException: Software caused connection abort: recv failed

When testing with a simple java https-client using the same keystore and truststore, by setting the exact javax-parameters on commmand line, the https-connection succeeds.

This indicates that there is a bug related to the way the build agent selects the keystore, or ignores some of the default javax.-parameters.
fields.summary: bamboo agent fails to build client certificate chain for https-connection

fields.description:
steps to reproduce:

1. create a multi stage, multi job plan where tasks take some time to execute.
2. create a manual branch and run it.
3. while the branch build is running, edit the plan and remove random job/stage.
4. ERROR -> observe that the branch build never finishes.. see screenshot.

Please note that attempting the same on a master plan will result in a warning that build is running and stuff should only be deleted afterwards.
fields.summary: endless branch build after deleting job in UI.

fields.description:
In Bamboo, we use "Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed" triggers to start a plan. It works fine but except for one case - when a plan is already building and someone pushes code to Stash repo during that build, it won't be picked up by Bamboo and won't trigger new build when the current one finishes.
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a Stash repo.
2. Create Bamboo plan. Add the Stash repo (do not enable quite period) and add Stash trigger to the plan.
3. Create a job that checks out the repo and a simple script task with "sleep 60" to make the build last about 60 seconds.
4. Commit and push some changes to the repo.
5. Observe how changes are picked up by bamboo, build is triggered automatically and runs for about 60 seconds.
6. When build finishes start it again manually.
7. Just after the build starts, commit and push new changes to the repo. This needs to be pushed while the manually-started build still runs.
8. Observe how the changes are never picked up by bamboo and how new build is never triggered.
fields.summary: Commits made to repository while a build is running should trigger a subsequent build

fields.description:
We have our own script to do release and push the bumped version of our project. However, bamboo will start a new build for the version bump commit, which will lead to an endless build loop. 
There's a configuration in repository level to ignore commits of certain pattern, it will be nice to have a global configuration as well.
fields.summary: Bamboo should have a global configuration for ignored commits

fields.description: Duplicating/Maintaining a task is too tedious. There should be a way to "favorite" a job or task so it will be added as a template when creating or reproducing a plan
fields.summary: Ability to "favorite" a job or task

fields.description:
When you configure a maven build you can check the option "The build will produce test results.".

If you enable this options and you have failing integration tests in your project, the project will build without displaying test errors.

The standard test directory is

"**/target/surefire-reports/*.xml"

The default setting should be changed to

{code}
**/target/surefire-reports/*.xml,**/target/failsafe-reports/*.xml
{code}

to include results from integration tests too, or another option should be added to include this test results too.
fields.summary: Scanning maven test results do not include integration test results per default

fields.description:
This may be expected behavior, if so feel free to close. 

We were trying to recursive copy files to maintain folder structure, but in one instance all of the files were under the same subfolder so the plugin didn't see it as a recursive copy.

Works fine
{noformat}
Matcher: **/*
dir1/subdir1/file1
dir1/subdir2/file2
{noformat}
Not viewed as recursive
{noformat}
Matcher: **/*
dir1/subdir1/file1
dir1/subdir1/file2
{noformat}
As a workaround, we added a useless file under dir1 which caused the plugin to view it as a recursive copy.
fields.summary: SCP Task Recursive copy doesn't work if only one folder has files.

fields.description:
Atlassian Bamboo version 5.6.0 build 4409 - 22 Jul 14

*How to reproduce:*

# Make sure a plan is on a given revision, let's assume for example _0xabcdef_ (you can also use "run customized" with this revision - same result - in this case skip step 2)
# Choose Run > Run plan from anywhere of the plan's interface
# Note the build number (let's assume its _TEST-10_)
# Go to {{/rest/api/latest/result/TEST-10.json?expand=results.result}} to verify that build is, in fact, there.

# Go to {{/rest/api/latest/result/byChangeset/abcdef.json?expand=results.result}}

*BUG:* there is no build for vcsRevisionKey _0xabcdef_ (which should be _TEST-10_).

*EXPECTED BEHAVIOUR:* /result/byChangeset should return manual build _TEST-10_ as it would any other build.
fields.summary: REST /result/byChangeset/ does not return manual builds

fields.description:
On the Build Dashboard, I can see the status (red/green) of each build triggered directly by each of my commits under "Latest Changes", and also the current state of each plan under "Favourite Plans". But I can't see what happened in between. 

Example sequence of events:
# I commit, the build is red (not due to my change - say it was already red)
# I can see the redness under both Latest Changes and Favourite Plans
# Someone else fixes the build. I can now consider myself happy: my commit did not break anything. But I don't look at the Build Dashboard at this time.
# Someone else breaks the build. The Favourite Plans entry goes red again.
# I look at the Build Dashboard to check if my commit was OK. Although it was, all I can see is red.

I think this could be solved by an extra status against each entry in Latest Changes, showing whether the build has ever passed since that commit.
fields.summary: Build Dashboard feature request: Show if build has ever passed since each of my commits

fields.description:
On the build expiry config page, {{admin/buildExpiry!edit.action}}, each of the "*Build and release artifacts only*" and "*Build and deployment result logs only*" checkboxes actually toggle the opposite checkbox's setting.

i.e. Selecting "*Build and release artefacts only*", and clicking *Save*, will show "What to expire   *Build and deployment result logs only*" on the {{admin/buildExpiry!read.action}} page, and vice versa.
fields.summary: Inconsistent checkboxes in Bamboo Build Expiry config

fields.description: For users utilizing repositories that are checked out via HTTP/S the credentials will need to be updated manually. In some cases there are multiple branches of the same repository defined as linked repos (as the branching model implemented doesn't work for every use case) and it would be nice for these customers if it was possible to bulk update the credentials of all of those repos in one go.
fields.summary: Ability to bulk update non-SSH credentials

fields.description:
Are there any capabilities currently in Bamboo to setup deployment rules?  In other words, we would like to be able to setup a 'promotion workflow' between environments to ensure that a release is approved before moving on to the next environment.

NOTE: Sarah Goff-Dupont mentioned this feature was on the short-term roadmap back in July 2013 in this article, http://blogs.atlassian.com/2013/07/release-management-jira-bamboo/.
fields.summary: Deployment rules

fields.description:
I'm currently moving our AID deployment plans from extranet-bamboo to identity-bamboo and it looks like we can't use the promote arrows or Promote All button in the aid-crowd or aid-openid dashboards (https://identity-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/deploymentDashboard).

I can promote via the All Deployment Projects page without issue so the plans/procedure seems to work fine, it's purely the dashboard.

In the dashboard, I click the Promote button, the pop-up appears, I hit Promote and then nothing happens.

You can try this yourself from dev -> staging without fear of breaking anything. Upgrades are seamless and you can release the same version multiple times.

Additionally it also no longer seems to work on the extranet-bamboo dashboard (which has been working for months).

Let me know if you require anything further.
fields.summary: Promote/Promote All buttons do not work in Bamboo dashboards.

fields.description:
bq. Trying to set up pull request restriction on https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/PFE/repos/dryad, which is built here: https://engservices-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/PEST-DRYAD
Unfortunately, Stash doesn't seem to be able to see the bamboo builds (it keeps telling me that a successful branch build is required, even though there are successful builds).

see https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/BUILDENG-7213 for details.

fields.description:
Our company uses multiple Atlassian products, like Jira, Confluence, Bamboo and Crucible. For source code control we are using PlasticSCM since it's the best state of the art tool for that. We have experiences with git, subversion, cvs and mercuical but all of them are not a patch on PlasticSCM. Unfortunately non of the Atlassian products supports PlasticSCM directly.

Currently we are using the PlasticSCM plugins provides by Codice. But most of the time there are not as nice integrated as the repositories which are directly supported by Atlassian. 

We think it is necessary for Atlassian to support PlasticSCM natively, since it's the best SCM system on the market, at least in our opinion. The native support would add value to all Atlassian products.

Especially Fisheye would benefit of a PlasticSCM support, since there isn't a plugin available yet. If you would integrate PlasticSCM support to Fisheye, we would immediatly buy a License for our Company. And I am sure others will do the same!
fields.summary: Adding Plastic SCM repository support

h4. Problem:

fields.summary: Paralleled builds running on greater than 20 agents causes artifacts discrepency

fields.description:
Bamboo currently only supports deploying (a) after a build completes or (b) following a certain schedule.

What I would like to happen is let me set a schedule - say, 2:00 AM, but only if a new build is ready to go.

I could just have my *builds* be scheduled, I suppose, but I'd prefer if it they were built after a commit, so that all the integration tests run while the humans are present.  I could clone the build project and have one be scheduled and the other per-commit, but that is gross.  I don't want to just re-deploy nightly unless there's a reason to.
fields.summary: Deployment triggers should be ANDed together

fields.description:
As a developer or someone in QA, I would like the ability to customize predefined variables in a deployment environment as part of the deployment process. For example, I may have a Staging environment that has a task in it which copies artifacts to a server by IP address. However, this IP is not fixed and the user should be prompted to set the value of the IP_ADDRESS environment variable prior to running the deployment environment tasks.

I have seen this customization available for build plans and I think it would make a fine addition to environments and deployment projects.
fields.summary: Allow parameterized deployments to environments
Escaping double quotes when using command can cause problems

fields.description:
We have discovered and fixed a vulnerability in our fork of one of Apache Struts libraries. Attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use these frameworks. The attacker needs to be able to access the Bamboo web interface.

All versions of Bamboo up to and including 5.7 are affected by this vulnerability.

The vulnerability has been fixed in recent releases 5.7.1 and 5.7.2.

For additional details see the full advisory.
fields.summary: OGNL Double Evaluation Vulnerability

fields.description: Allow customization of the Jira Issues view in Bamboo. Example, add _Resolution_ column to the display.
fields.summary: Customise Jira Issues view

fields.description:
Since Docker arrived I'am playing around with it quite a bit. 
Currently I'm curious how to integrate docker in my deployment process using bamboo.

Bamboo has a bit of a static Environment Configuration, which was fine at a time where I had just a fixed number of environments.
But since docker arrived I can basically create one complete environment (multiple containers) within a small script in no time. 
This allows me to easily create multiple environments for different branches. 
But in bamboo I would now have to create one environment per container manually.

I would suggest something similar to the plan branches where I have a basic environment and if I want to deploy an artifact I can choose to automatically create a new environment from this template or choose an existing one. This template would contain tasks to create containers, link them, etc


The current workflow looks like that:
- Developer creates new docker container(s) with bash script
- Developer creates new environment in bamboo (basically clones an existing one)
- developer deploys artifact to this environment

...at some point developer deletes environment in bamboo and (hopefully) removes all running containers
fields.summary: Plan Deployment Environments
